ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: this is one of the top courses i took at fes, largely because it provided an intellectual foundation fornot only speaking about the major themes of FES courses, but it provided a framework for being critical of it when necessary. this is as intellectually rigorous a class as you will take during your time at FES, but the payoff is surprisingly high, even if the class seems arcane and difficult at first. i feel far more capable of posing vital questions of assumed and received reasoning in the environmental context, not something FES is very good at fostering but something that it should be far more interested in doing if its intentions are really to train leaders.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: The readings were interesting once I learned how to navigate the terminology and thematic content.

the readings were difficult but eye opening. the group of students in this class was probably the best thing about it. karen was a great presence, but really she just kind of moderated a very heated weakly meeting between 15 very different but very engaged students. this is a discussion seminar, so the group mix is of vital importance. we lucked out.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: Discussion could be more structured. It is a long class period, and prone to being monopolized by certain individuals.

i don't know how to suggest this, as i don't want any material shaved from the class, but there were times when i felt pretty lost with what we were talking about and there was really no time to go back and set an intellectual foundation for it. karen's management of that might have been missing a bit. also, for a masters student in FES, discussion would be more useful if we got down to practical matters a bit more often. discussion weighed heavily toward the theoretical, sometimes dominated by anthro phds. i suppose changing this would have been up to the FESers, but it wasn't easy.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: Offered a lot of critical material that was lacking from other FES courses.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: it was the only class of its type offered by FES. this is a shame.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: Yes, I learned more than I expected, and was able to think through my own research interests.
absolutely. though i'm still working through it all.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Take advantage of the readings, discussions, and professor. They are all excellent resources.
at first this class may seem over your head. but if your schedule allows it, try to stick with it. you will be changed.
